title: Flight to Egypt
shortSummary: Jeremiah 43 recounts the disobedience of Johanan and the remnant of Judah who refuse to heed God's command to remain in the land and instead flee to Egypt. God reveals through Jeremiah a prophecy of judgment against Egypt by Nebuchadnezzar, demonstrating His sovereign control over nations and His judgment against those who reject His word.
timeline: c. 586 BC - After the fall of Jerusalem and the Babylonian exile, during the early years of the Babylonian captivity

keyCharacters.name: Jeremiah
keyCharacters.description: The prophet of God who faithfully delivers God's commands and warnings to the people, including the command not to flee to Egypt.

keyCharacters.name: Johanan son of Kareah
keyCharacters.description: A military leader who leads the remnant of Judah to disobey God's command and flee to Egypt.

keyCharacters.name: Baruch son of Neriah
keyCharacters.description: Jeremiah’s scribe, accused falsely by the people of inciting them against their own interests.

keyCharacters.name: Azariah son of Hoshaiah
keyCharacters.description: One of the leaders who challenges Jeremiah’s prophecy and accuses him of falsehood.

definitions.definition: Another name for the Babylonians, the empire that conquered Judah and carried many into exile.
The captain of the Babylonian guard who oversaw the destruction of Jerusalem and the exile of its people.
A city in Egypt where the remnant of Judah settled after fleeing, and where Jeremiah received further prophecy.
A place where bricks were made, used here as a symbolic location for Jeremiah to hide stones as a prophetic sign.

outline.heading: Jeremiah’s Prophecy Rejected
outline.description: Jeremiah finishes delivering God’s message, but the leaders and people reject it, accusing Jeremiah and Baruch of lying and conspiring against them. Despite God’s command to remain in Judah, Johanan leads the people to disobey and prepare to flee to Egypt.

outline.heading: The Flight to Egypt
outline.description: The remnant, including women, children, and royal family members, depart for Egypt, directly disobeying God’s instructions, demonstrating a lack of trust in His protection and sovereignty.

outline.heading: God’s Prophetic Sign in Egypt
outline.description: While in Tahpanhes, God commands Jeremiah to hide large stones in the clay of a brickkiln as a visible prophetic sign to the people of Judah present there.

outline.heading: Judgment Announced Against Egypt
outline.description: God declares through Jeremiah that Nebuchadnezzar, His servant, will invade Egypt, bringing destruction and captivity. This prophecy highlights God’s control over all nations and His judgment on those who oppose His will.

application: Obedience to God’s word is essential even when it contradicts our fears or plans; trusting God’s sovereignty brings true security.
Rejecting God’s commands can lead to greater judgment and hardship, as seen in the flight to Egypt and the coming Babylonian invasion.
God’s prophetic warnings are given out of love and a desire to protect His people; we must listen attentively and respond in faith.
Remember that God’s authority extends over all nations, and He uses even foreign rulers to accomplish His divine purposes.

keyVerses.text: But Johanan the son of Kareah, and all the captains of the forces, took all the remnant of Judah, that were returned from all nations, whither they had been driven, to dwell in the land of Judah;
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the leadership’s decision to act contrary to God’s command, setting the stage for the consequences of disobedience.

keyVerses.text: And say unto them, Thus saith the LORD of hosts, the God of Israel; Behold, I will send and take Nebuchadrezzar the king of Babylon, my servant, and will set his throne upon these stones that I have hid; and he shall spread his royal pavilion over them.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals God’s sovereign use of Nebuchadnezzar as His instrument of judgment against Egypt and those who disobey Him.

keyVerses.text: And when he cometh, he shall smite the land of Egypt, and deliver such as are for death to death; and such as are for captivity to captivity; and such as are for the sword to the sword.
keyVerses.significance: This prophecy underscores the certainty and severity of God’s judgment on Egypt for harboring His disobedient people.
